Q1. $T(n) = 3T(\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor) + n$

From the recursion tree, we find that the tree structure dominates the the cost; that is, there are the expected $\lg{n}$ levels, but each level costs more than the one below. We have the expected cost at $\sum_{1 \le i \le \lg{n}}{c_i \cdot i}$ for all $c_i \ge 2$.

While I was unable to use this to come up with a strong guess (other than perhaps $n^{\lg{n}}$), the master theorem does tell us that $T(n) \in \Theta(n^{\lg{3}})$, so I will use that and the substitution method. From the proof below, it is evident $n^{\lg{n}}$ would have worked as well, despite being less tight.

Ignoring floors:

So, we wish to prove $\exists c \gt 0, d : \forall n \gt 0 : T(n) \le cn^{\lg{3}} + dn$ by induction on $n$. We assume the base case $T(1) = 1 \le c + d$, we have that constraint on $c,d$.

Assume that $\forall k \lt n : T(k) \le ck^{\lg{3}} + dk$.
Then $T(n) = 3T(\frac{n}{2}) + n \le 3(c\left({\frac{n}{2}}\right)^{\lg{3}} + \frac{dn}{2}) + n$ by the induction hypothesis
So $T(n) \le \frac{3cn^{\lg{3}}}{2^{\lg{3}}} + \frac{3dn}{2} + n = cn^{\lg{3}} + dn + n\frac{d+2}{2} \le cn^{\lg{3}} + dn$ when $\frac{d+2}{2} \le 0$, or $d \le -2$.

Then choose $d=-2, c=3$.

$T(n) \le 3n^{\lg{3}} - 2n \in O(n^{\lg{3}})$

Q2. $T(n) = T(\frac{n}{2}) + n^2$

From the recursion tree, we have the sum $\sum_{1 \le i \le \lg{n}}{(n + \frac{n^2}{2^i})} \in O(n^2)$ if we unroll (we have something like $n\lg{n}$ and $n^2\sum_{1 \le i \le \lg{n}}{\frac{1}{2^i}} = n^2 (2 - \frac{2}{n}$).

So we will prove $\exists c \gt 0 : \forall n \gt 0 : T(n) \le cn^2$ by induction on $n$. 
The base case gives $T(1) = 1 \le c$.

Assume that $\forall k \lt n : T(k) \le ck^2$.
Then $T(n) = T(\frac{n}{2}) + n^2 \le \frac{cn^2}{4} + n^2$ by the induction hypothesis.
Then $T(n) \le n^2 \left( \frac{c}{4} + 1 \right) \le cn^2$ when $c \ge \frac{4}{3}$.

So choose $c = \frac{4}{3}$. Then $T(n) \le \frac{4}{3}n^2 \in O(n^2)$.
